title: The Juggernauts and Riot's Direction
body:
Am I the only person that actually thinks the Juggernauts are a great addition to the game?

Sure they are strong but i think everyone forgets that Riot is going to go through every class of champions and do this. Marksmen are next. The game is evolving and I think it is great. 

Imagine if Riot didn't implement champions with a ton of mobility, loaded kits, or unique abilities. Heimer would be pick or ban because no one would be able to touch him. Ashe would be the best ADC in the game right now. The list goes on. 

My only beef with Riot is that they do all these awesome updates and put out these great champs but dont update the old champs to kee pthem fresh and viable as the game switches pace and direction.

If riot kept up on that the game would be amazing and balanced but as it is right now, new champions/reworked champions get these insane kits while they never update old champion's kits like Anivia or Pantheon. Can you win with those champions? yeah sure you can. Is it harder? yeah it is. Why pick Anivia when you can pick Azir whos kit is way more overloaded then Anivia does Anivia's zoning job better, and has mobility?

My point is that I think everyone is getting mad over the Juggernauts because they throw the game into a completely new direction and people want to hold onto the old Champions and the old way of the game. 

People need to accept that a game evolves and is normally for the better

Riot needs to accept that if they change a game this heavily they need to be prepared to update the old things in the game

replies.body:
> Riot needs to accept that if they change a game this heavily they need to be prepared to update the old things in the game

We totally agree with you on this. The unfortunate fact of the matter is there is a lot of "old" stuff in the game to update, and it really does take a good share of time to get to them all. I know the player base doesn't always agree with some of the champions we choose for updates, but we do try to choose ones that we think are in the most need. As to champions like Anivia or Pantheon, these are characters that commonly come up in "who should we update next" meetings, so they're definitely not off the radar.

As to Juggernauts and player sentiment around them, my personal opinion is that we probably still have some fine tuning follow-up to do to them in the upcoming patches, and then hopefully they'll be in a good long term spot. The goal of big changes like the Juggernaut changes is definitely to find these somewhat antiquated characters a new niche/home in the game, and we are pretty fully aware we won't hit the mark on all of them, especially on the first try. I'm personally pretty excited for pre-season, because as a designer on champions, it means I have a lot more freedom to explore ideas for champions without them being such a huge risk to game balance down the stretch.

I appreciate the response and I do agree most times with your direction. I have loved every champion that you have released since i first started playing when Yasuo was released, and I think you do a great job with keeping the game fresh and updated and pushing it towards great things. 

It is kind of a give and take subject for me because i want to see all of these old champions reworked and have their kits changed to be in tune with recently released characters, but i do understand how hard it is to not only do that and put the character back into current play with an updated kit, but to also keep that said character relative to their old identity. It is a tough task that i think Riot does a great job at, and that is why I am willing to wait the time needed. 

The Fiora rework, the Gangplank Rework, and the Juggernaut additions are perfect examples of why sometimes waiting longer can yield much greater results. I was honestly amazed at how Gangplank and Fiora were changed to make them fit into a great part of the game AND you made their core identities even better. 

Everybody complained that Skarner, Garen, Darius, and Morde didn't have enough mobility to exploit their kit, but you kept their core identity and built into the immobile crazy damage dealing tanks and kept that identity while giving obvious strengths and weaknesses that match their level of "We may be slow but when we get a hold of you all hell will break loose" mentality. also the follow up tweaks have been good and i can see the juggernauts settling in great after two patches more or so.

I hope you guys keep doing what you do and making crazy awesome champions that change the game while still keeping that old flavor in there with previous champions by updating them. 

Sincerely,

One happy customer

P.S. You guys have been doing a super awesome job responding on the forums of late. The community appreciates that.

Gangplank still doesn't have a dash, either.  In fact, I think he completely lost the move speed steroid from his old kit so he is now *more* immobile.  But he's not only viable, but banworthy and nerfworthy.  Mobility isn't the only worthwhile thing about a champion.
You forgot he has a refreshing 30% MS boost, on his passive and barrels, so most of the time GP _is_ more mobile than he was.

The "juggernaut" role has been around for forever... Riot just gave it a new name and buffed a few champions who fill this role. Garen, Darius, morde, skarner, olaf, shyvana, dr. mundo, volibear... all these champions fit the bill. They are all sustained damage melees with low-middling cc and limited mobility. Most of them have very similar play patterns, benefit from similar items, etc. 

I think the role is pretty binary by nature. But there's no reason to believe that the reworked juggernauts are fundamentally un-balanceable. A lot of the champions I listed above do tend to be particularly sensitive to meta shifts, but they have all enjoyed plenty of time when they are strong but balanced picks. If it's possible to balance volibear/shyv/mundo/olaf, it's possible to balance reworked Garen/darius/skarner.

Morde is the only real wildcard, IMO. He brings a lot of pretty unique and very specific strengths to the table. I'm not sure what the future holds for him.

Just wanted to say, as far as Anivia goes, she really just needs a few changes.

Her wall not blocking allies would be great and/or blocking all forms of movement except teleports and blinks, being able to keep channeling her ulti while CC'd (the ability has more than enough counterplay as it is) would be small changes as far as implementing them but huge in terms of how Anivia plays in the current LoL landscape.

I support this idea, I don't want to see a rework where she changes her play patterns, her build paths or anything like that which has me very scared for her when I hear riot talking about champion updates

>As to champions like Anivia or Pantheon, these are characters that commonly come up in "who should we update next" meetings, so they're definitely not off the radar.

How does one champ get decided over another?  Do you guys go for the more popular champs?  Lowest hanging fruits (easiest to fix)?  Ones that don't need a VU as well?  Do you pick the unpopular but hard to fix champs first?  Do you look at the recent reworks that failed and get back to them?  Do you pick problems similar to ones you just worked on?  For example, the juggernauts just got reworked.  So what about the old school immobile mages, are they up next?

It's a combination of things usually. To name a few things...

* What designer(s) are available?
* What kind of production assets are available?
* Does the champion need a Sion-level rework? Or something more like Fiora? Or even as small as Ashe?
* Are there immediate game health concerns with the champion?
* Could we accomplish similar results with small kit-based changes?

Maybe tweak the numbers so that her mana costs aren't quite so abusive early game, and change her AA animation so that it doesn't feel like utter shit to farm pre-6.

Seeing Juggernauts in action, I mainly see that they are effective, but... swingy. When they're good, it's easy for people to think "oh holy hell they're completely OP" without actually analyzing and seeing what they had to do to achieve such a success.

Darius, for example, has a lot of gameplay around his Q heal not proccing if you're next to him. That probably needs to be cleaned up to be more visible(heal lines going into darius?) or made a little more forgiving for people to learn about that. Or.... there just needs to be more counterplay like that so people get in the habit of looking for things like that. Not sure.

Technically juggernauts have been around for a while. They just haven't been defined as such.

Regardless, it is really cool to see the juggernauts be a big force to be reckoned with. In recent memory, most immobile melee champions have either never been very good due to not being able to reliably get to their targets and not doing anything once they do get to their target, have been completely broken in the past due to having degenerate gameplay mechanics to compensate for their immobility, or otherwise have a lot of baseline utlity that they didn't always need to get to their targets to have an impact.

Now, these juggernauts have the tankiness to get to their targets and the damage to make an impact once they get to their targets. Some of them might be a little bit strong right now, but designwise I think it's perfect.

Of course, that's only four immobile champions out of however many immobile champions we have in the game. For quite a while many new champions have been getting some sort of mobility on their kit almost for free, leaving many immobile champions in really bad spots. It would be really nice to bring many of them up to where their lack of mobility is a weakness and accounts for them having greater strengths elsewhere rather then having a lot of weaknesses, including that lack of mobility.
